metadata.titleEn: Dataset of the water-balance-based evapotranspiration of global typical large river basins (1983-2016)
metadata.description: This is the water-balance-based evapotranspiration (ETwb) dataset for 56 large (> 105 km2) river basins of the world over the 1983–2016 period. Specifically, ETwb = Prec − Q – dS, where Prec, Q, and dS (all in mm yr−1) are basin-averaged annual precipitation, runoff, and the change in terrestrial water storage, respectively. For each basin, the observed Q at the hydrological station, four different Prec (GPCC, CRU, MSWEP, GPCP), and three types of dS (JPL, GSFC, CSR) estimates are used, yielding altogether 12 annual ETwb time-series. An optimally merged ETwb time-series is eventually produced using the Bayesian-based three-cornered hat method for each basin, which is probably the most appropriate one for benchmarking ET models.
metadata.instructions:
The data include two main folders “ETwb_Data” and “River_Basin_Boundary”:
1.     ETwb_Data
 The “ETwb_Data” folder contains two sub-folders called “ETwb_12Members” and “ETwb_BTCH_Merged”, respectively. All data are for 56 basins over the 1983–2016 period. Please see the Table 1 below for the Basin ID (e.g., Basin_1, Basin_2…Basin_56) shown in the first line of each Excel file.
(1)      The “ETwb_12Members” sub-folder contains 12 Excel files named in the format of ETwb_PrecType_dSType, in which PrecType represents precipitation from GPCC/ CRU/MSWEP/GPCP and dSType represents dS from JPL/GSFC/CSR.
(2)      The “ETwb_BTCH_Merged” sub-folder contains the optimally merged ETwb of the 12 members using the Bayesian-based three-cornered hat method. This data is recommended as the benchmark for validating/calibrating global ET models.
2.     River_Basin_Boundary
The “River_Basin_Boundary” folder contains two sub-folders called “ShapeFile” and “netCDF”, respectively. Both are for the boundary of 56 river basins. You may choose any of them for use in processing the gridded data.
(1)      The “ShapeFile” sub-folder contains the shape files of the river basin boundary, which could be used in the ArcGIS software. The detailed information is shown in the “Attribute Table”. The “Basin ID” in the “Attribute Table” is identical with that in the Figure 1 and Table 1. This ShapeFile is recommended for users who are familiar with ArcGIS.
(2)      The “NetCDF” sub-folder contains the river basin boundary in the NetCDF format (River_Basin_Mask_56.nc). This basin mask data is at 0.25°, which is appropriate for processing any gridded data with geographical coordinates. The Integer in this NetCDF file ranges from 1 to 56 that is same with the Basin ID in Figure 1 and Table 1. This NetCDF file is recommended for users who prefer to use self-programming to process the data.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the data collection methods used to measure actual evapotranspiration for large river basins?
Feature Specification.Answer: hydrological station observations of runoff, four different precipitation products (GPCC, CRU, MSWEP, GPCP), three types of water storage change data from GRACE/GRACE-REC (JPL, GSFC, CSR), error correction in precipitation products

Quantification.Question: What is the number of large river basins included in a dataset focused on global water balance and evapotranspiration?

Definition.Question: What does 'water balance method' mean in the context of estimating evapotranspiration in large river basins?
Definition.Answer: The 'water balance method' refers to a technique used to estimate actual evapotranspiration in large river basins by calculating the difference between observed runoff, precipitation products, and changes in water storage. This approach utilizes data from hydrological station observations and multiple precipitation products while considering error corrections to enhance accuracy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying causes that necessitate the use of multiple precipitation products and water storage change data when calculating evapotranspiration in large river basins?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The utilization of multiple precipitation products (GPCC, CRU, MSWEP, and GPCP) and water storage change data (JPL, GSFC, and CSR from GRACE/GRACE-REC) is necessary to ensure accuracy and account for potential errors, as each product offers varying perspectives and corrections on precipitation and water storage changes. This approach helps in refining the evapotranspiration calculations by mitigating biases inherent in individual data sources.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on the accuracy of estimated actual evapotranspiration when combining multiple precipitation products and water storage change data for large river basins over a long time period?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Combining multiple precipitation products and water storage change data can improve the accuracy of estimated actual evapotranspiration by allowing for error correction and providing a more comprehensive view of hydrological dynamics. This approach leverages diverse data sources to account for discrepancies and enhances the reliability of the results by incorporating a broader range of observations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to combine and correct multiple precipitation products to ensure accurate inputs for estimating actual evapotranspiration in large river basins?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Precipitation products are combined and corrected for errors by considering multiple data sources such as GPCC, CRU, MSWEP, and GPCP. These products are evaluated for discrepancies and adjusted to improve accuracy, ensuring reliable inputs for calculating actual evapotranspiration using water balance methods.
